title: 1986년 Stanley L. Davis v. Robert Herring, Sheriff of Lee County, Mississippi and Edwin L. Pittman, Attorney General of the State of Mississippi 사건
summary: 미국 USA, Federal 법원 판결 사건. 사건명: Stanley L. Davis v. Robert Herring, Sheriff of Lee County, Mississippi and Edwin L. Pittman, Attorney General of the State of Mississippi. 판결일: 1986-09-26. 법원: Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
description:
## 사건 정보

**사건명**: Stanley L. DAVIS, Petitioner-Appellee, v. Robert HERRING, Sheriff of Lee County, Mississippi and Edwin L. Pittman, Attorney General of the State of Mississippi, Respondents-Appellants
**판결일**: 1986-09-26
**법원**: Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
**관할**: USA, Federal

**판사**: Randall, Rubin, Williams

## 변호인

Bill Patterson, Donald G. Barlow, Edwin L. Pittman, Atty. Gen., Jackson, Miss., for respondents-appellants., Duncan Lott (Court Appointed Co-Counsel) Joe Ray Langston, Booneville, (Court Appointed), Booneville, Miss., for petitioner-appellee.

## 인용

- 800 F.2d 513

## 판결문 요약

800 F.2d 513
    Stanley L. DAVIS, Petitioner-Appellee,v.Robert HERRING, Sheriff of Lee County, Mississippi and EdwinL. Pittman, Attorney General of the State ofMississippi, Respondents-Appellants.
    No. 83-4421.
    United States Court of Appeals,Fifth Circuit.
    Sept. 26, 1986.
    
      Bill Patterson, Donald G. Barlow, Edwin L. Pittman, Atty. Gen., Jackson, Miss., for respondents-appellants.
      Duncan Lott (Court Appointed Co-Counsel) Joe Ray Langston, Booneville, (Court Appointed), Booneville, Miss., for petitioner-appellee.
      Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi.
      Before RUBIN, RANDALL, and WILLIAMS, Circuit Judges.
      ALVIN B. RUBIN, Circuit Judge:
    
    
      1
      The panel has decided, sua sponte, to vacate its earlier opinion in this case,1 and to substitute instead the following.
    
    
      2
      The habeas corpus petitioner fired his pistol into a tavern, killing the owner.  Indicted separately for both murder and the felony of shooting into an occupied building, he was tried on the murder indictment alone.  When the jury convicted him only of manslaughter, the State attempted to prosecute him in a second trial for the shooting felony.  He objected on double jeopardy grounds, and, after exhausting his state remedies, obtained an injunction in federal court against the second prosecution.
    
    
      3
      The murder statute under which Davis was tried requires the State to pro...
